candidates.title: release version 0.7.0
candidates.body: Things have changed quite a bit since 0.6.0!

candidates.title: use an asynchronous queue to submit blocking operations
candidates.body:
We now use a bounded channel that yields to the scheduler when it is
full. This is desirable because we want to apply backpressure to
user-code in those cases rather than to allocate or block.

candidates.title: update dependencies
candidates.body: Pin our dependencies to the latest non-api-breaking version.

candidates.title: add a stall detector that logs stacktraces of unyielding tasks, redux
candidates.body:
### What does this PR do?

This PR supercedes https://github.com/DataDog/glommio/pull/417 . I believe all the concerns raised there are addressed in this implementation.

This PR adds a rudimentary stall detection mechanism to Glommio.

It measures the runtime of task queues and logs if they don't yield when
they are due.

Knowing if a queue is stalling the reactor is nice, but finding the
exact code location where the stall occurs remains very hard. Especially
if a task queue hosts many concurrent fibers.

To help with that, this PR introduces a stall detection mechanism that
records stack traces of stalling tasks. It works as follows:

- When a task queue is scheduled for execution, we set up a timer that
triggers some time after the queue is expected to yield (we add a 10%
error margin to avoid false positives). A background thread collocated
with the local executor waits on the timer at all times.
- When the timer fires, the thread sends a signal (SIGUSR1) to the
local executor thread. Upon receiving the signal, the local executor
records a complete trace of the local stack. Here we take advantage of
the fact that by default, the kernel invokes signal handlers on top of
the existing stack. i.e. the frames we record are those of the
problematic user code that was meant to yield. The recorded frames are
pushed on a non-blocking communication channel that links the signal
handler and the local executor.
- When a task queue yields, the local executor disarm the timer and
checks the communication channel for potential recorded frames, if there
are any then we can conclude that the queue stalled, so we log them.

This code works in practice but has two major drawbacks:

- The timer dance is expensive; expect a high number of syscalls.
Because of this runtime overhead, the stall detector is disabled by
default. To opt-in, you  must pass in something that implements
`StallDetectionHandler` when constructing the `LocalExecutor`. There
is a concrete `DefaultStallDetectionHandler` that uses `SIGUSR1` and 
logs a warning log message.
- We log stalls only after the queue yield. Therefore, if there is a bug
in your code and your queue never yields, the stall detector will never
log the code location that's at fault (even though we probably have
recorded the trace by then). The reason for this is that logging from a
signal handler is illegal.

candidates.title: add a benchmark that measures how IO performs when competing with CPU
candidates.body:
This adds a new benchmark that creates a CPU intensive, throughput
oriented task queue alongside a latency-sensitive IO queue.

candidates.title: add a way to measure and report IO latency
candidates.body:
Add the plumbings necessary to measure various kinds of IO latency,

We now keep track of two kinds of IO latency: 
* The time sources spend in the ring, including the submission queue;
* The post-reactor scheduler latency, or the time the scheduler takes to
come back at the tasks that consume the IO;

We now export them as distribution in the `IoStats` struct. And this PR
adds distribution support to Glommio. We use "sketches" that give a 
statistical approximation of quantiles because we want the overhead 
(space and time) to be low when recording latencies.

A side effect of this is that pulling the stats from the reactor now
clears them (because a distribution needs to be cleared regularly to be
helpful). I don't expect this to be problematic because, in practice,
users want rates from the stats and keep the previous values in memory
to compute deltas. This should, therefore, greatly simplify this logic.

candidates.title: update dependencies to avoid depending on the `chrono` crate
candidates.body:
The `chrono` crate has a security vulnerability, and the ecosystem is
moving away from it, so should we (also it annoys me that `cargo-check`
doesn't pass anymore because of this).

See https://rustsec.org/advisories/RUSTSEC-2020-0159 for details.

Cargo-check can't be configured to tolerate vulnerabilities in dev
dependencies right now. It's a feature request, so maybe it'll come one
day:
https://github.com/EmbarkStudios/cargo-deny/issues/322

candidates.title: sort the caro dependencies, because why not
candidates.body: There really IS a cargo tool for everything

candidates.title: add benchmarks for tcp socket
candidates.body: Two benchmarks added to compare tcp socket performance between glommio and tokio for echo/proxy server.

candidates.title: Reduce foreign wake latency
candidates.body:
### What does this PR do?

Reduce foreign wake latency by sending notifications via the event fd installed on the latency ring. Notifications will only be sent if the task being waken was spawned on a queue with latency requirement. A comparison between with and without notifications produced by the foreign_wake benchmark:

```
$ RUST_LOG=debug RUST_BACKTRACE=1 cargo bench --bench foreign_wake 
    Finished bench [optimized] target(s) in 0.04s
     Running unittests (target/release/deps/foreign_wake-6d33a328eb2cc763)

Latency requirement: NotImportant
Label              Min   Mean    P99  P99.9    Max
glommio->tokio:  0.014  0.285  0.614  0.822  0.902
tokio schedule:  0.000  0.008  0.055  0.123  0.178
tokio process :  0.515  1.962  2.965  3.067  3.161
tokio->glommio: 11.816 96.668 97.983 99.135 99.135

Latency requirement: Matters(100ms)
Label              Min   Mean    P99  P99.9    Max
glommio->tokio:  0.000  0.169  0.399  0.518  0.564
tokio schedule:  0.000  0.018  0.100  0.176  0.213
tokio process :  0.513  1.794  2.415  2.717  2.873
tokio->glommio:  0.004  0.374  0.633  0.677  0.730
```

What inspired you to submit this pull request?

for this Pull Request.

candidates.title: update `nix` to 0.23
candidates.body:
0.22 has a security vulnerability. See https://rustsec.org/advisories/RUSTSEC-2021-0119 for details.
This new version marks some enums with `#[non_exhaustive]` to force downstream users to match against wildcard. See https://doc.rust-lang.org/reference/attributes/type_system.html#the-non_exhaustive-attribute.

### What does this PR do?

A brief description of the change being made with this pull request.

candidates.title: add CI checks to make sure our dependencies are clean
candidates.body:
This PR adds a new CI check that:
* makes sure our dependencies are permissively licensed;
* makes sure our dependencies are "free" of security vulnerabilities;
* assert that the `LICENSE-3rdparty.csv` file contains an
authoritative list of all our dependencies and their respective
licenses.

In the process, I had to update our dependencies (some of them were 
outdated).

### What does this PR do?

A brief description of the change being made with this pull request.

repo.name: glommio
repo.description: Glommio is a thread-per-core framework that aims to make the task of writing highly parallel asynchronous applications in a thread-per-core architecture easier for rustaceans.

repo.name: glommio
repo.description: Glommio is a thread-per-core crate that makes writing highly parallel asynchronous applications in a thread-per-core architecture easier for rustaceans.
